created_at: ZIM had around $3 billion of net cash on its balance sheet at the end of the most recent quarter -- for a company that is valued at $2.65 billion
column3: that is incredible. Note that this does not account for ZIM's lease liabilities

body: But as JPM and many others have argued
created_at: including these lease liabilities in the net cash calculation does not make a lot of sense -- ZIM does not pay any interest
column3: and the lease liabilities go hand in hand with an asset-like right of use for the respective vessels. ZIM's current net cash position is thus larger than its market capitalization -- which means that the company is clearly priced for a downturn.

body: If ZIM burns through half its current cash position over the next two years
created_at: which is a pretty bearish estimate
column4: then ZIM would still hold a net cash position of around $1.5 billion at the end of 2024 -- or close to 60% of the current market capitalization.
